sub_topic: Schwarz reflection principle and its applications
message_1:
Suppose that $f(z)$ is an analytical function in the upper half plane $\operatorname{Im}(z) > 0,$ which has a continuous extension to the real axis, i.e., $f(x)$ is continuous for $x \in \mathbb{R},$ such that $f(x) \in \mathbb{R}$ for $x\in\mathbb{R}.$ Moreover, $f(z)$ satisfies the following conditions:
$$\lim_{R\to \infty} R\left(f\left(R e^{i\theta}\right)-1\right)=0,$$
$$\lim_{R\to \infty} R f'\left(R e^{i\theta}\right)=1,$$
for all $\theta \in (0,\pi).$

Determine the function $f(z)$ using Schwarz reflection principle.
message_2:
To determine the function $f(z)$ using the Schwarz reflection principle, we first define a function $g(z)$ that is analytic in the lower half-plane, $\operatorname{Im}(z) < 0$, and has a continuous extension to the real axis such that $g(x) = f(x)$ for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. We can define $g(z)$ as the complex conjugate of $f(\bar{z})$, i.e., $g(z) = \overline{f(\bar{z})}$.

Now, we define a new function $h(z)$ as follows:
$$
h(z) = \begin{cases}
f(z), & \text{if } \operatorname{Im}(z) > 0, \\
g(z), & \text{if } \operatorname{Im}(z) < 0.
\end{cases}
$$

Since $f(z)$ and $g(z)$ are continuous on the real axis and $f(x) = g(x)$ for $x \in \mathbb{R}$, the function $h(z)$ is continuous on the real axis. Moreover, $h(z)$ is analytic in both the upper and lower half-planes. By the Schwarz reflection principle, $h(z)$ must be an entire function, i.e., analytic in the whole complex plane.

Now, let's consider the function $F(z) = z(h(z) - 1)$. From the given conditions, we have
$$
\lim_{R \to \infty} F(Re^{i\theta}) = 0,
$$
for all $\theta \in (0, \pi)$. Since $F(z)$ is an entire function, by the Riemann's theorem on removable singularities, $F(z)$ must be identically zero in the upper half-plane. Similarly, we can show that $F(z)$ is identically zero in the lower half-plane. Therefore, $F(z) = 0$ for all $z \in \mathbb{C}$, which implies that $h(z) = 1$ for all $z \in \mathbb{C}$.

Finally, we have $f(z) = h(z) = 1$ for all $z$ in the upper half-plane, and this is the unique function that satisfies the given conditions.
